I seldom use Cover Flow mode in iTunes and never in the Finder, but for web page history, it strikes me as downright useful — perfect for finding a page when you don’t remember the name or URL, but you do remember what it looked like.
From John Gruber’s Safari 4 Beta observations. As far as I’m concerned the Cover Flow view in iTunes and especially in the Finder is a useless gimmick. But after browsing website history with Cover Flow in Safari 4 I’ve found it remarkably practical and useful, it seems to have found it’s place.

§ Mar 9th, 2009

The Switch to Tumblr

After 5 years using a self-hosted WordPress installation I’ve switched to Tumblr. The tumblelog has been renamed and valhallaisland.com points here now. A complete mirror of the old Valhalla Island sits at archive.valhallaisland.com and the FeedBurner feed points to the Tumblr feed URL. All this stuff might take a while to settle down.

Just last week I wrote about how I’d love to use Tumblr but couldn’t work out where it fit between Valhalla Island, Twitter and other online services. I started using it, trying to let it find it’s own place.

Using Tumblr is the joy that I didn’t know I’d lost in blogging. I love the Tumblr platform, UI, the community and the brilliant content people are using it to create. The feeling around Tumblr now is the feeling there was around WordPress five years ago.

After my trial period Tumblr’s place still wasn’t exactly clear, I continued to struggle with where I should publish and I didn’t like having to separate myself into personal and semi-professional categories. What was clear after the trial was that I enjoyed posting to Tumblr more than I have enjoyed posting to the blog in a long time. In my infinite quest to consolidate and find the ideal setup and workflows it made sense to merge WordPress into Tumblr.

You can expect the same level of editorial quality here as you could at the old Valhalla Island (whether you consider it high or low) but with a thicker stream of content including more personal and not-necessarily-related-to-computers stuff.

Every link on the internet that pointed to a post at Valhalla Island will now be broken, there’s nothing I can do about it and I’m not bothered, it feels good to start fresh.

Switching to Tumblr means relinquishing complete control of every minute detail involved in running a blog. I see it as a positive thing. Tumblr lets me ignore the details and just post. I can still completely customise the look of my tumblelog and if ever I need it the API let’s me at my raw data.

It feels great to be excited about publishing again.

§ Feb 24th, 2009

maniacalrage:

Why don’t we have solar panels on the hood and roof of our cars? Cars sit outside in the sun all day, especially in cities. I know they couldn’t draw enough power to function, but every bit of gas we don’t have to use seems like a good idea.

The sun is just sitting up there. Let’s use it.

I’ve had exactly the same thought about lining the roofs of houses with solar panels. They’re far more likely to be sitting in the sun all day. Why not commit it to law that roofs must be lined with solar panels?

§ Feb 23rd, 2009

Losing Everything

No matter where you are in the world you’ve probably heard about the devastation of the Victorian Bushfires over the last few weeks. Over two hundred people lost their lives and thousands more lost everything they owned.

Today was a national day of mourning and my girlfriend and I were talking to her Mum about the loss. She couldn’t believe how people could deal with losing everything.

A bit of back story. My girlfriend has a huge family that’s lived in the same huge house on a huge block of land for the last 19 years. They keep everything.

As long as you were fully insured, I’d see it less as loss and more of a fresh start. As much as I think about it, I can’t think of a possession I own that couldn’t be replaced by money. But what about the photographs?! All the best are hosted at Flickr and the rest are backed up at MobileMe. Any printed photographs I own originated as digital files I’ll still have.

I’ve found a lot of people have sentimental and emotional attachments to material things: cars, furniture, computers, phones. When I sold my piece of shit car, my Mum asked if I said good bye to it. No, I didn’t, because it’s just a mass produced hunk of metal and plastic.

Already someone who doesn’t believe in sentimental value, who throws away anything that has no practical use, spending four months overseas living out of a single backpack made it clear how easy it was to live with even less. While the shock of “losing everything you’ve worked your whole life to attain” would be great at first, I’m sure many of the bushfire victims who’s friends, family and pets are still alive will soon realise how little they’ve lost in the big scheme of things.
